task.title: Creating a VPC with a Private Subnet

context.p: This task describes using the command line tools to create a VPC with a public and a private subnet. IMPORTANT: This topic isn't finished yet!

step.cmd: Create a VPC with a CIDR address range of /16 (this will allow for 65,535 IP addresses in your VPC).

step.cmd: Create a public subnet for your VPC.

step.cmd: Create a private subnet for your VPC.

info.p: This command should return output similar to the following:
info.codeblock: SUBNET subnet-347f5e3f available vpc-72ad7f86 10.0.1.0/24 251 one false false

step.cmd: Attach the Internet gateway to your VPC.

This command should return something similar to the following, showing an attachment to your VPC:

step.cmd: Create a security group for your new VPC. You'll need the identifier of the VPC you created. In this example, the identifier is vpc-72ad7f86.

info.codeblock: euca-create-group mysecuritygroup -d "My test security group" -c vpc-72ad7f86

info.p: This command should return output similar to the following:
info.codeblock: GROUP sg-8c4bb9ef mysecuritygroup My test security group

step.cmd: Add rules to your new security group to allow inbound traffic. In this example, we'll allow HTTP, HTTPS, and SSH:

info.p: This command should return output similar to the following:
info.codeblock: GROUP sg-8c4bb9ef PERMISSION sg-8c4bb9ef ALLOWS tcp 80 80 FROM CIDR 0.0.0.0/0

info.p: This command should return output similar to the following:
info.codeblock: GROUP sg-8c4bb9ef PERMISSION sg-8c4bb9ef ALLOWS tcp 22 22 FROM CIDR 0.0.0.0/0

info.p: This command should return output similar to the following:
info.codeblock: GROUP sg-8c4bb9ef PERMISSION sg-8c4bb9ef ALLOWS tcp 443 443 FROM CIDR 0.0.0.0/0
